abstract.p: Bill Ball letter on Alex Witchel's June 14 article on ordering tap water in restaurant

block.p: Alex Witchel's article made a recent dining experience in Paris even more memorable. The multi-level Colette, a modern design shop on the Rue St.-Honore, also has a cafe on the lower floor. Alex Witchel's article made a recent dining experience in Paris even more memorable. The multi-level Colette, a modern design shop on the Rue St.-Honore, also has a cafe on the lower floor. On a drizzly day in May, it seemed like a good spot for lunch, so we settled in over a couple of glasses of Cotes-du-Rhone.

Our waiter advised us that this was also a water bar and suggested we peruse the list of some 50 waters. Amused, we asked him to recommend a water to accompany our roast chicken, and he returned with a 600-milliliter bottle of King Island Cloud Juice containing, according to the label we've saved, ''7,800 drops of pure rainwater.'' After I observed that there was more than enough rainwater outside, he quickly reassured us ''but this rain fell in Australia!''
